global_summary: This hearing session focuses on credible testimony from former United States Air Force personnel regarding Unidentified Flying Object (UFO) encounters at nuclear missile facilities, supplemented by historical research into the phenomenon. The central theme is the consistent pattern of UFOs appearing over sensitive nuclear sites, demonstrating capabilities far beyond known technology, and in some cases, actively interfering with the operational status of intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs). The hearing opens with Captain Robert Salas's detailed account of the March 1967 incident at Malmstrom Air Force Base, Montana, where ten Minuteman missiles simultaneously became non-operational as a UFO hovered nearby. Salas provides evidence of an official cover-up, including forced non-disclosure agreements and the deliberate withholding of information from the Condon Committee, which he argues was a pretext to publicly dismiss the UFO phenomenon. This testimony is corroborated by other witnesses detailing similar events. Captain David Scindelli describes a 1966 incident at Minot Air Force Base, North Dakota, where a UFO sighting coincided with an entire flight of ten missiles going offline. He too was ordered by the Office of Special Investigations (OSI) never to speak of it. Tech Sergeant David Scott recounts a 1974 event at Minot AFB where a UFO caused widespread alarms and electrical failures across multiple missile sites. Captain Bruce Fenstermacher shares his 1976 experience at F.E. Warren Air Force Base, Wyoming, involving a cigar-shaped object observing launch facilities, a report met with ridicule by his command post, followed by orders to destroy his notes and maintain secrecy. Researcher Richard Dolan provides historical context, presenting declassified FBI and Air Force documents from the late 1940s and 1950s that detail repeated UFO incursions over critical nuclear installations like Hanford, Los Alamos, and Oak Ridge. A recurring element throughout the testimonies is the culture of secrecy and ridicule within the military, which discouraged reporting and created a lasting psychological burden on the witnesses. The hearing concludes with a Q&A session where the panel of former congressional members discusses the implications of this long-standing secrecy, the potential origins of the objects, similar incidents reported in the former Soviet Union, and the institutional failure of projects like Project Blue Book to conduct a genuine scientific investigation.

topics.title: Captain Robert Salas's Testimony on the Malmstrom AFB Missile Shutdown Incident
topics.summary: The hearing begins with the witness panel being sworn in. Captain Robert Salas, a former U.S. Air Force missile launch officer, provides his testimony regarding a UFO incident on March 24, 1967, at Malmstrom Air Force Base, Montana. While on duty at the Oscar Launch Control Center, he and his commander, Lieutenant Frederick Mywald, witnessed all ten of their Minuteman I nuclear missiles inexplicably shut down. This occurred immediately after security personnel reported a large, red, pulsating oval-shaped object hovering over the facility's front gate. The missile failures were diagnosed as guidance and control system faults. Salas presents audio recordings of a later conversation with a retired Colonel Mywald confirming key details of the event. He also reveals that a similar shutdown, the Echo flight incident, had occurred a week prior. Following the incident, Salas and his commander were forced to sign non-disclosure agreements. He argues that the Air Force deliberately covered up these events, specifically by denying information to the Condon Committee, whose 1969 report was used as the basis for terminating Project Blue Book and officially dismissing the UFO phenomenon as a national security threat. Salas concludes that the Air Force has engaged in a long-standing campaign of disinformation.

topics.title: Captain David Scindelli's Testimony on the Minot AFB November Flight Incident
topics.summary: Captain David D. Scindelli, U.S. Air Force (retired), gives public testimony for the first time about a UFO incident in 1966 at Minot Air Force Base, North Dakota. As a deputy missile combat crew commander for Minuteman ICBMs, he was scheduled for duty at November Flight shortly after hearing a local news report about strange lights seen near Mohall, North Dakota. At the pre-departure briefing, it was mentioned that missiles at November Flight had gone off alert. Upon arriving at the facility, the site manager described a large, silent object with flashing, pulsating lights that had hovered just outside the perimeter fence before moving directly over the underground launch control capsule. When Scindelli and his commander went below ground, they found all ten of their nuclear-tipped missiles were off alert and unlaunchable, a situation they had never seen before. The outgoing crew confirmed the missiles malfunctioned while the object was directly overhead. The next morning, security personnel were instructed not to discuss the incident, and Scindelli's commander informed him they had been ordered by the Office of Special Investigations (OSI) to never speak of it again.

topics.title: Tech Sergeant David Scott's Testimony on a 1974 UFO Sighting at Minot AFB
topics.summary: Tech Sergeant David Charles Scott, a retired Air Force Security Policeman, recounts his UFO sighting in November 1974 while stationed at Minot Air Force Base. He and another airman were dispatched to a missile site for an alarm. En route, they noticed a strange, pulsating red light in the sky. While investigating the secure missile site, the light grew larger and began changing colors. Suddenly, their vehicle's engine and radio died simultaneously. After about 45 minutes, the light, now white, pulsated three times and vanished, at which point their engine and radio came back to life. Upon returning to their launch control facility, their flight security controller informed them that he believed their story, as all Minuteman missile site alarms in the wing had sounded at the same time, and many other security teams had reported seeing strange lights and experiencing similar radio and vehicle power failures. The controller dissuaded them from filing an official report, warning they would be ridiculed. Scott later heard a Canadian radio broadcast about the Canadian Air Force scrambling jets to pursue a UFO on the same night, which he believes was the same object.

topics.title: Captain Bruce Fenstermacher's Testimony on the 1976 F.E. Warren AFB Incident
topics.summary: Captain Bruce Fenstermacher, a former Minuteman III combat crew commander, describes a UFO incident from the fall of 1976 at F.E. Warren Air Force Base, Wyoming. While on duty in the underground capsule at Romeo Launch Facility, he overheard radio traffic where his topside security controller directed a Security Alert Team (SAT) to observe a bright, white pulsating light in the sky. The controller described the object as a silent, 40-50 foot long, "fat cigar" hovering directly above the launch facility. The object then moved slowly over two other missile silos. Fenstermacher's attempts to report the incident to the SAC command post were initially met with laughter and disbelief. He later learned from another missile crew at Quebec flight that they had seen a similar object heading toward his location earlier that night. The SAT team at his facility repeatedly failed to deploy to the silos, and he was later told they refused to go near the object. The next morning, his squadron commander confiscated and destroyed his and his deputy's personal notes on the incident and forced them to sign non-disclosure documents. Years later, he connected with a member of the Quebec SAT team, who described seeing the object project a beam of light onto a launch facility.

topics.title: Researcher Richard Dolan on Historical UFO Incidents at Nuclear Facilities
topics.summary: Researcher Richard Dolan provides historical context on the connection between UFOs and national security, specifically at nuclear facilities since the dawn of the atomic age. He begins with a non-declassified account from a U.S. Navy officer about a July 1945 incident where six F6F Hellcat fighters were scrambled to intercept a massive, high-altitude, saucer-like object hovering over the Hanford Atomic Facility in Washington. Dolan then transitions to declassified documents obtained via the Freedom of Information Act. He cites FBI memos from 1949 and 1950 describing repeated incursions of sensitive airspace over Los Alamos by unknown objects, including "green fireballs" and brilliant white disks. Another set of documents details multiple radar and visual sightings over the Oak Ridge, Tennessee atomic facility in 1950, which led Army Intelligence to issue a high alert for any data on "flying saucers." He concludes by referencing an Air Force memo about continued sightings over the Hanford plant in 1950, which triggered an alert for all units, including anti-aircraft battalions. Dolan argues these events show a clear and persistent interest by an unknown intelligence in America's most vital nuclear infrastructure, leading to the profound secrecy that still surrounds the topic.

topics.title: Panel Q&A on Secrecy, Foreign Incidents, and Project Blue Book
topics.summary: The hearing panel of former members of Congress questions the witnesses. The discussion begins with the difficulty of estimating the size of UFOs and the lack of recent press coverage on such incidents. The panel inquires about similar events occurring over Soviet missile bases. Captain Salas and Captain Fenstermacher recall reports of a 1982 Soviet incident where a UFO allegedly initiated a missile launch sequence, which was subsequently aborted. Richard Dolan adds that during the final years of the USSR, there was a period of openness where the Soviet military reported several dramatic encounters, acknowledging the objects were far beyond any known terrestrial technology. The panel then asks the witnesses why they are breaking their oaths of secrecy now. Captain Salas explains that he began speaking after the incident was partially revealed in a book and the Air Force declassified related files, though he later realized his specific incident remained classified. The discussion turns to Project Blue Book, which witnesses describe as a "whitewash" designed to publicly debunk UFOs, not investigate them. Dolan explains that Blue Book was intentionally gutted after 1952 on CIA orders to minimize the number of 'unknown' cases. The session concludes with Congresswoman Wolsey reflecting on the professional risks that prevent sitting politicians from addressing the topic, and expressing hope that this hearing will encourage more openness.
